captions.text: I want to share a little secret,

which I hope will not be a secret 
by the end of the talk.

I am truly, madly, deeply passionate 
about the human brain.

Science has taught us 
that our brain shapes us,
that it makes us uniquely who we are.

And if we think about our brain,
it has 200 billion neurons.

Think about the world's population: 
that's a mere 7 billion.

And we have hundreds of trillions 
of connections in our brain.

If we imagine all the stars 
in the Milky Way Galaxy,

there are more connections in our brain, 
than all of those stars combined.

So, this incredibly complex organ 
that we carry with us

everywhere we go, 
it does shape who we are.

It is a filter, 
it filters our perceptions

and our understanding of ourselves, 
of others, of our world,
and of our place in that world.
And, what is incredibly amazing
is no two brains are exactly alike.
If you look at the person next to you,

and you note 
all the physical differences between you:

the shape of your nose, 
the color of your eyes, your height,

there are more differences 
between your two brains

than all of those physical differences 
in combination.
So, our brain does make us uniquely us.

And I am here today 
to share with you my story,
and it's a story of how I came to learn
that not only does our brain shape us,
but that we can actually shape our brain.
My story began in Grade 1,

and in Grade 1 I was identified 
as having a mental block.
I was told I had a defect.

And I was told I would never learn 
like other children.

And really, the message at that time 
was loud and clear.

I was told I needed to learn to live 
with those limitations.

And this was 1957, and it was the time 
of the unchangeable brain.

And childhood was 
a profound struggle for me.

I couldn't tell time. 
I couldn't understand the relationship

between an hour hand 
and a minute hand on a clock.

I couldn't understand language. 
Most of what I read, or heard,

was really as intelligible 
as the 'Jabberwocky'.
I could understand concrete things.

If somebody said to me, 
"The man is wearing a black coat",

I could paint the picture in my head, 
and I could understand that.

But what I couldn't do was understand 
concepts, or ideas, or relationships.
So, lots of things were confusing.

I pondered, how could my aunt also 
be my mother's sister?

And what did that fraction, 
1/4, really mean?

Any kind of abstract concept 
was hard for me.
Irony and jokes: that was impossible.

So, I learned to laugh 
when other people did.

Cause and effect: 
it did not exist in my world.

There were no reasons 
behind why things happened.

My world was a series of disconnected 
bits and pieces of unrelated fragments.

And eventually, 
my fragmented view of the world

ended up causing 
a very fragmented sense of myself.

And that wasn't all: 
this whole left side of my body

was like an alien being, 
unconnected to the rest of me.

I would bang and bump into things 
on the left side of my body.

If I picked up anything in this left hand,
I would drop it.

If I put this left hand on the hot burner,
I would feel pain,

but I had no idea 
where it was coming from.
I was truly a danger to myself.

My mother, she was convinced 
I would be dead by the age of 5.

And then, if that wasn't enough, 
I had a spatial problem.

I couldn't imagine 
three-dimensional space.
I couldn't create maps in my head.

I would constantly get lost,
even in my friend's house.
Crossing the street instilled terror.

I could not judge 
how far away was that car.
Geometry was a nightmare.
I felt incredible shame.

I felt there was something horribly, 
horribly wrong with me.

And in my child's mind, 
when I'd heard that diagnosis,

of having a mental block, 
I actually thought

I had a wooden cube in my head 
that made learning difficult.

And I didn't have a piece of wood 
in my head, but I wasn't far wrong.
I had blockages, as I was later to learn,
in very critical parts of my brain.

And I tried all the traditional approaches, 
they were all about compensation,
and about working around the problem,
finding a strength to support a weakness.

They were not about trying to address 
the source of the problem,

and they took heroic effort, 
and led to rather limited results for me.
Then, Grade 8.
I hit the wall.

I could not imagine 
how I could go on to high school,
and handle more complex curriculum.

The only option I could see 
was ending my life.
So, I decided to end the pain.

And the next morning, when I woke up 
after my failed suicide attempt,

I berated myself for not even being able
to get that right.
So, I soldiered on.

And part of what kept me going was 
an attitude that I learned from my father.

He was an inventor, and he was passionate 
about the creative process.

He taught me that if there's a problem,
and there's no solution,
you go out and create a solution.
And the other thing he taught me was

that before you can solve a problem, 
you have to identify its nature.

So I continued my hunt. 
I went on to study psychology,

to try to understand 
what was wrong with me,
what was the source of my problem.

And then, in the summer of 1977, 
something life-altering happened.
I met a mind like my own,

A Russian soldier, Lev Zasetsky, 
the only difference being
his mind was shaped by a bullet,
and mine had been that way since birth.

I met Zasestky on the pages of a book,
'The Man With a Shattered World',

wrtitten by the brilliant Russian
neuropsychologist, Alexander Luria.
As I read Zasetsky's story,

he couldn't tell time, 
he described living in a dense fog.
All he got was fragments, bits and pieces.
This man was living my life.
So now, at the age of 25, in 1977,
I knew the source of my problem.

It was a part of my brain, in the left 
hemisphere, that wasn't working.

And then I came across the work 
of Mark Rosenzweig,
and he showed me a solution.
Rosenzweig was working with rats,

and he found that rats in an enriched 
and stimulating environment
were better learners.

And then he went 
and looked at their brains:

their brains had changed physiologically 
to support that learning.
And this was neuroplasticity in action.

Neuroplasticity, simply put, 
the brain's ability to change

physiologically and functionally, 
as the result of stimulation.
So now I knew what I had to do.

I had to find a way to work, 
to exercise my brain,
to strengthen those weak parts.

And this was the beginning of 
my transformation and of my life's work.

And I had to believe that humans must have
at least as much neuroplasticity,
and hopefully more, than rats.
So, I went on to create my first exercise.

And I used clocks, because clocks 
are form of relationship,
and I had never been able to tell time.
So I started with the two-handed clock,

to force my brain 
to process relationships,

and then I added a third hand, 
and then a fourth hand,

because I wanted to make my brain 
to work harder, and harder, and harder,

to pull together concepts 
and understand their connection.
And about three to four months in,
I knew something significant had changed.

I'd always wanted to read philosophy, 
and had never been able to understand it.

And I just happened to have access 
to a philosophy library.

So I went in, 
and I pulled a book off the shelf,
and I opened it to a page at random,

and I read that page, 
and I understood it as I was reading it.
This had never happened in my entire life.

And then I thought, maybe it's a fluke, 
maybe that was just an easy book.

So I pulled another book off the shelf, 
opened it, read it, and understood it.

And by the time I was finished, I was 
surrounded by a pile of a hundred books,

and I had been able to read 
and understand each page.
So I knew that something had changed.
(Applause)
Thank you. My experiment had worked.
The human brain was capable of change.
And then I decided to create an exercise
for that alien part of my body,

and for that I knew I had to work 
on an area in the right hemisphere,

the somatosensory cortex 
that registers sensation.

I created an exercise for that 
and I am no longer a danger to myself.
And then I decided, that spatial problem,

because I was really tired 
of getting lost,

and so I created 
another exercise for that,

and I don't get lost, I can actually 
read maps -- I don't like GPS's,

because I like to read maps now, 
because I can. (Laughter)
So, I knew now, the brain could change.

I was living proof 
of human neuroplasticity.
And what really breaks my heart
is that I still meet people today,

children, individuals, that are struggling
with learning problems,

and they're still being told 
what I was told in 1957,

that they need to learn to live 
with their limitations,
they don't dare to dream.
And what I learned since 1977,

when I met Zasetsky and Luria, 
and Rosenzweig,
is that, yes, our brain does shape us,

it impacts how we can engage, 
and participate, and be in the world,
and every single one of us

has our own unique profile 
of cognitive strengths and weaknesses.

And if there's a limitation, 
we don't necessarily have to live with it.
We now know about neuroplasticity,

and we can harness 
the brain's changeable characteristics,

to create programs to actually strengthen 
and stimulate and change our brain.

And in 1966, Rosenzweig 
threw down the gauntlet.

He said, his challenge was: 
"Let's take what he'd learned with rats,
and apply it to human learning."
And we need to embrace that challenge,

we need to also challenge 
current practices

that are still operating out of 
that paradigm of the unchangeable brain.

We need to work together to take 
what we know now about neuroplasticity,

and develop programs 
that actually shape our brains,
to change the future of learning.
My vision is of a world that we create,
in which no child has to live

with the ongoing struggle and pain 
of a learning disability.

My vision is that cognitive exercises 
become just a normal part of curriculum.

My vision is that school becomes a place 
that we go to strengthen our brain,

to become really efficient 
and effective learners,
engaged in a learning process,

where not only, as learners, 
can we dare to dream,
but we can realize our dream.

And to me, this is the perfect marriage 
between neuroscience and education.
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: The Woman Who Changed Her Brain: Barbara Arrowsmith-Young at TEDxToronto

comments.text: Our brains capabilities are beyond our imaginations﻿
comments.author: Mansour Ali

comments.text: Done similar (to) myself.  If there's a Will, there's a Way﻿
comments.author: KOZMOuvBORG

comments.text:
I had a similar thing, I couldn't tell time or do algebra or know why 
monday goes before tuesday, I would only know what day it was or what month 
if I asked somebody etc. 
Somehow years later something suddenly clicked in middle school and I knew 
alot of stuff I didn't know before. And then again later in highschool. 
There are still a few problems, such as Algebra. I forget it as soon as I 
wake up the next day no matter how hard I try. Now in college there is only 
Algebra for math but no one understands how hard it is for me. :/ I have 
failed it 3 times and could be kicked out of college if I fail my next one. 
I would ace geometry any given chance...but just algebra is a true struggle 
all my tutors have given up on me.﻿
comments.author: WhiteWolfos

comments.text:
Fantastic story. A perfect representation of the success mindset. What your 
father taught you is worth more than gold.﻿

comments.text:
+Anonymous Nobody "I have labeled and sequentially correlated them."


Isn't it obvious that your labeling system was understood, considering both 
quotes given were prefixed by "(1)" in your original reply.

Furthermore, why are you asserting that sequentially correlated information 
implies a relationship of proof. That's a logical fallacy.

Lastly, you did not label and sequentially correlate them. You labeled 
them, therefore they became sequentially correlated.
comments.author: Jay Celler (Orgmented)

comments.text: I have labeled and sequentially correlated them.
comments.author: Anonymous Nobody

comments.text:
+Anonymous Nobody "Science has taught us that our brain shapes us, that it 
makes us uniquely who we are.""(The brain) It is a filter, it filter's our 
perceptions and our understandings"

"Young girl has a damaged brain, everyone "believed" the physical brain was 
static."

How does your quote from Barbara back your statement?
comments.author: Jay Celler (Orgmented)

comments.text:
+Jay Celler (1) 0:24.. -"Science has taught us that our brain shapes us, 
that it makes us uniquely who we are." 1:11.. --"(The brain) It is a 
filter, it filter's our perceptions and our understandings" (2) 8:35.."Simply 
put, the brains ability to change physiologically and functionally" 8:57.."And 
I had to BELIEVE that humans had as much neuro-plasticity, and hopefully 
more, than rats" (3) 11:11.. "And what really breaks my heart is that I 
still meet people today, children ..individuals that are struggling with 
learning problems, and they are being told what I was told that they need 
to learn to live with their limitations."

(1)Young girl has a damaged brain, everyone "believed" the physical brain 
was static. (2)Young girl discovers a man with a damaged brain that thinks 
like her. Young girl learns about super enriched environments and rats 
behavior. Young girl BELIEVES she can change her physical brain. <-------- 
That is the most important part of this complete speech.
(3)Adult woman knows children do not believe they can change like she knows 
they can. <---Therefore they can't change, because they don't believe they 
can.

What changes us, is our beliefs, the brain is a computer, that deletes 
information through filters (value systems) set up by external inputs and 
chooses the most cogruent belief. The brain wants to be told what to do and 
not to do, it will change physical form based on external input...and WE 
control that input...that is the most salient point of this speech.
comments.author: Anonymous Nobody

comments.text: wow...

comments.text: Thank YOU for your Courage & Self-Belief... AWESOME LADY!!! *=}﻿
comments.author: Indigo Elle

comments.text:
We are our own worse enemy. I'd been being haunted by victim mode for a 
long long time and I didn't notice it. By self-teaching myself psychology 
and English(information quality and transparency are much better) I learn 
the phrase "victim mode". 

By defining victim mode(blaming others, complaining, stay silent without 
reacting, don't fight for our own rights, quit taking the wheel of your 
fate, being distant etc. etc.) helps me spot where I am and stay on the 
direction I of my goal.

I am no longer a danger to myself. I am a living proof of human brain 
plasticity. 
06:32 :Attitude learned from her farther:if there's a problem and there's 
no solution you go out and create a solution. before you can solve the 
problem you have to identify it's nature. Great parenting!!!

Thanks for the speech.﻿
comments.author: Jiashen Huang

comments.text:
+temtem naotem Not necessarily, neuroplasticity was discovered after an old 
man who had had a massive brain stroke, relearned to do everything again. 
He was a professor, he even went back to his job.
comments.author: Jackie Levaggi

comments.text:
It's a very tricky way of solving handicaps. You won't read what I've said 
anywhere - it's just my oppinion. With age, maybe during illness, we do not 
have strength enough to maintain such an effort. I think it will happen to 
the brain what happens to the body - decline and fall are certain as we age.

I knew a lady that suffered of dislexia and tried a new aproach to solve 
her problem; as she learned a new language, she learned again her native 
language. I felt some enthusiasm about that approach, but now I think that 
as age limit our capabilities, dislexic persons will be dislexic again, not 
only in her native language but also in the new language.

Continuous learning along life may slow down that decline; I don't know 
enough about that. 

Very interesting +Nina Anthonijsz . Thanks.
comments.author: temtem naotem

I really liked this woman's story and how it helped her get smarter and 
overcome her challenges. But I feel like this will only work for certain

comments.author: Courtney Harmon

comments.text:
+Courtney Harmon 5 years ago, was on 800mg/day Seroquel, have since 
whittled that down to 50mg/day. Lost 60 lbs. too, no Gym or diet, now that 
I can think much better, can take care of myself likewise
comments.author: KOZMOuvBORG

comments.text: +KOZMOuvBORG Good for you!
comments.author: Courtney Harmon

comments.text:
+hoozerob That diagnosis is actually a garbage can, 25% of (all) cases get 
labelled such. Since THEY don't really know what's going on, you tend to 
get the worst treatment. Despite valid health problems, those tend to get 
dismissed as 'in your head'. 

But… 5 years ago, had a Spiritual Experience, prompted by an experimental 
kind of Seroquel but that turned a tad manic enough to study psychology, 
along with self-refection, figured out by myself that I have Asperger's. 

Took a while, but convinced my Shrink, after showing him an MRI image down 
for research, couldn't deny the shape of my medial cerebellum. Since then, 
my medical problems are getting dealt with. 

Not long after the 'Awakening', realized that I'm transgender and getting 
hormones and surgery has been approved. 
Couldn't do that until re-assessed

Never been HAPPIER any other (extended) time of my Life
comments.author: KOZMOuvBORG

comments.text:
+Anonymous Nobody Someone like me, who has Schizo-affective disorder(hate 
to be one of those who put names to things, but it is accurate for me), 
though I generally know up from down and left from right, my brain tells me 
it's something else, regardless. or, trying to remember or comprehend, but 
picturing a puzzle with missing pieces or pieces in the wrong places. so my 
brain wants to replace those missing ones with anything that might make 
sense or make up for the loss. Or maybe just take the ones in the wrong 
space and just force them to fit somewhere else, or just remove them 
because it can't deal with them. A fast paced world, that I have never been 
able to keep up with in my own little section of town. My brothers 
surpassed me in every conceivable way. I have always been behind, right 
from the start. I am not much passed a middle school student mentality. 
Ironically, I had hung out with and felt more comfortable around them(my 
son, stepdaughters, their friends) many times when they were younger. or 
the neighbors kids would come out to hang out with me. somehow they must 
have felt that I was mentally on their level as well. I don't get where it 
seems my development stopped. I have always done poorly in school. couldn't 
concentrate for long, drift off and zone out, get burnt out. mind my starts 
on another interest, gets burnt out shortly, then on to another thing , 
then back again usually. there are always missing information when I think. 
things get twisted, missed, forgotten. On top of all of this, my mind has 
constant clutter. memories that I beat myself up over, the life long lazy 
gene effect which has always been there. just can't move or even think a 
lot of the time, just sit and stare is all I can muster up to do. A small 
task seems monumental,  worries about usually nothing really big, music 
playing or talking. all the time. my head is like an old radio with all of 
the stations coming on at once. What do I do with all of this. How can one 
manage to function. all my life, going through this. I have been on the 
suicidal track most of my life. I fear that one day I will snap and just do 
it to escape the pain.
comments.author: hoozerob

comments.text:
Just like you. I find something that seems at least a little interesting 
and could possibly help. But I fall out of trying, lose interest, didn't 
get enough out of it. Then I just quit. No more motivation again. I started 
going to a neurologist, but with my kind of insurance, they take everything 
one month at a time. How is that suppose to help? initial visit and 
bloodwork "see you next month". "let have an MRI", then, "See you next 
month". I don't live my life one month at a time. But all doctors seem to 
be getting this way now. Is this all part of the Obama cut backs?
comments.author: hoozerob

comments.text:
+hoozerob http://raiseyouriq.com I haven't tried it myself but I have been 
trying to find a lot of information about it and it actually sounds very 
promising. They have their own youtube channel as well. 
https://www.youtube.com/user/RYIQ

There is a technique called Image Streaming that I tried a few months ago 
and I felt it gave a slight improvement in my visualization skills. But I 
only tried it for five days before I got sick and had to stop for a while. 
I still haven't found the motivation to continue. Here's a few sites:
http://howtobecomesmarter.org/image-streaming/
http://www.winwenger.com/imstream.htm

comments.author: Rosemary Smith

comments.text:
I am in the process of listening this and I cannot help but feel sometimes 
science does more damage than good. All these so called pseudoscience and 
New Agey technique has more pragmatic benefits than an armada of skeptics 
whose sole task is to push forth atheistic agenda like religious zeal. In 
logic class, students are told not to question their "PHD" professors, in 
psychology cynical teachers don't want to look beyond their boundaries and 
of course in psychiatry and medicine, alternative medicine is frowned upon.

Think of hypnosis and Mesmer, think when atom was considered indivisible, 
think when we were taught that brains were fixed, think of IQ 
studies....may be in the future all these mind-body theory will be common 
sense as the above ones are now. Ironically it is the same science that 
unravels and discovers new frontiers.


It helps to be open minded. And I would rather have my brain fall out 
instead be narrow minded "scientist" with answer to all of life's question.﻿
comments.author: Lao Tzu

comments.text:
Why must we always assume scientists are close minded...I mean do you feel 
that way about Stephen Hawking. It's such a difficult combination of 
circumstances that set this woman up for the difficulties that beset her. A 
system that was non-functioning, some doctors, not all...Why must we 
generalize to a whole population. If a whole population of people who are 
trying to do good in a field constantly hear how bad they are why should 
they continue to try. It is like any other thing in this world...without 
having to polarize the situation...there is good and bad. And she did 
manage to find doctors that did help her. The answer for each of us can't 
be given to us by a doctor or by any other person...just wish sometimes we 
could see situations for what they are as opposed to reducing them to the 
simplest of elements. It's like saying a sunset is light bending, happens 
in the evening, every day and can be pretty. Hardly like actually seeing a 
sunset!
comments.author: ramblin rose

comments.text: I totally agree!

comments.text:

comments.author: Lao Tzu

comments.text:
+Lao Tzu never heard anyone call themselves Lao Tzu...ever see the "God" 
facebook page? At any rate your point is lost in her perspective. She's 
advocating for scientific change. And she's also showing exact opposite 
examples of what you point out and saying that indeed change and progress 
can and IS happening. I know learned professors that don't use 
"pseudoscience" but also believe in alternative healing and a sense of 
"communitas" uphold "New Agey" techniques in their own personal lives. And 
I don't get what you mean by your generalization of "New Agey" technique. 
Exactly what logic classes are you talking about? Classic Logic...that'd be 
the basics you describe. Frankly at 52, I find a lot of positivity in both 
New Age and also Scientific work in the arena of neural plasticity. I don't 
know where you live but alternative medicine seems to be making great 
strides in many health "arenas." My ex boyfriend was actually prescribed a 
holistic formula for cancer treatment (granted he doesn't live in the 
United States). Perhaps, in the days of old, you're point could be more 
substantiated - but I remember growing up in the sixties and while we have 
a long way to go...we have also come a long way.

comments.author: Dustin Robertson

comments.text:
+Dustin Robertson (1) 0:24.. -"Science has taught us that our brain shapes 
us, that it makes us uniquely who we are." 1:11.. --"(The brain) It is a 
filter, it filter's our perceptions and our understandings" (2) 8:35.."Simply 
put, the brains ability to change physiologically and functionally" 8:57.."And 
I had to BELIEVE that humans had as much neuro-plasticity, and hopefully 
more, than rats" (3) 11:11.. "And what really breaks my heart is that I 
still meet people today, children ..individuals that are struggling with 
learning problems, and they are being told what I was told that they need 
to learn to live with their limitations."

(1)Young girl has a damaged brain, everyone "believed" the physical brain 
was static. (2)Young girl discovers a man with a damaged brain that thinks 
like her. Young girl learns about super enriched environments and rats 
behavior. Young girl BELIEVES she can change her physical brain. <-------- 
That is the most important part of this complete speech.
(3)Adult woman knows children do not believe they can change like she knows 
they can. <---Therefore they can't change, because they don't believe they 
can.

What changes us, is our beliefs, the brain is a computer, that deletes 
information through filters (value systems) set up by external inputs and 
chooses the most cogruent belief. The brain wants to be told what to do and 
not to do, it will change physical form based on external input...and WE 
control that input...that is the most salient point of this speech.
comments.author: Anonymous Nobody

comments.text: +Dustin Robertson and that IS the bigger point of this piece, eh?

comments.text:
+Doppler If you're actually interested in learning more about 
neuroplasticity, allow me to make a recommendation. Norman Doidge, M.D. 
authored a book titled "The Brain That Changes Itself". It is a New York 
Times Bestseller and it's 2nd chapter is a similar but more detailed 
version of Barbara Arrowsmith's story. Each other chapter is another true 
story relating to neuroplasticity from just about every point of reference 
one might consider. It's something like $20 and you can probably find it at 
your local bookstore. Enjoy.

comments.author: sizesmall 1756

comments.text:
+sheraine zeffrienne Thank you Sheraine.  I've led a stressful life most of 
my life.  Though I loved to read, I had difficulty remembering whatever I 
just read.  I would (and still do) forget the names of people I've known 
for years.  I would just go completely blank.  I would forget pin #'s I had 
used many times.  I knew something wasn't "right", but I never sought 
help.  I am now convinced that the stress is the reason my brain has never 
functioned properly.  Like you, I'm reading and listening to anything that 
has to do with how to control and manage stress.  Thanks for your comment.  
I now feel like there's hope.
comments.author: IW Nunn

comments.text: Thanks!
comments.author: Stefan Lay

comments.text:
Hi Stefan .There is hope! I was diagnosed with ptsd and clinical 
depression. I could not remember anything! I had massive memory gaps. I 
could not focus. If I read anything, it would not stay put..I could not 
hold on to any new information or retrieve old info. I read everthing I 
could ( over and over ) about how stress affects the brain. The amygdala 
(alarm system in the brain) is on full alert and your neocortex shuts down 
and along with it, all your higher order cognitive skills. Your hippocampus 
(where some memories are processed) shrinks and your memory is seriously 
affected. I began to practise mindfulness and eventually I was able to 
alter my stress response. It was a fairly long process but now my memory is 
sharp and I can retain and use new information. I am no longer depressed 
and I changed by befriending my brain and learning to turn off the stress 
response! A very simple basic life changing exercise.. breathe in through 
your nose and out through your mouth. Breathe slower on the exhale. This 
deactivates the stress response. Once out of stress mode, your body and 
brain can begin to heal. Do it as many times as u can throughout the day 
..set little reminders. Just a couple of these breaths regularly. The 
hippocampus can regrow neurons. You can get your short term memory back!! 
Good luck.
comments.author: sheraine zeffrienne

comments.text:
yeah, amazing that it's possible to improve/bring back cognitive abilities 
after years of depression and stress or anxiety. prescriptions meds can't 
quite do it though. books are way better. and regular practice.

With no conceptual thinking, cause-effect understanding, with kinesthetic 
disability she must've been completely illiterate and physically 
handicapped by age 25. And over sudden she started to make use from

she's learnt it overnight), she developed her cognitive exercises (isn't 
she Nobel Price laureate yet?).. If one who's philosophy-ignorant but 
otherwise street smart open Hegel at random page, she won't understand 
anything. Ability to understand concept definition (which is rear in the 
middle of a book) is one thing and understanding concepts' relationships 
that comes only with practice is another.
I've worked with the physically unfit and retarded  of bloated by "spec ed" 
self-esteem.. oh, that sucks. I wouldn't stay there even if my wage were 
tripled.

self-healing case - was the cancer in the first place?

this good thing will happen. He must want it to change (his situation) 
otherwise he will never get better. I know how it is when you are broken, I 
was given my last rites when I was a young man, fractured my skull, broke 
my whole right side of my body in a car accident, a priest had given me my 
last rites, doctors said I was going to die, I was in a coma for 12 and a 
half days. But I am here because I believe in the good. I attained a 
Masters in Computer Science and I am going for more things because I can. 
It isn't science it is internal. It is what you believe. Screw all the ones 
that fear life because those are the ones who will try to bring you down to 
their level.
